Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Representative of HW bowl SZ S1/2. FC in lower pack is slowly healing and mid pack brick very well consolidated. Lee S1/2 Sz currently hold stubborn trending unreactive Swd

Shallowest Part of the Towers 5 SZ. Mid pack very dense consolidated brick. DH at ground showing first signs of rounding with some edges rounding- Failures still present in test results. IFrc 230601 not present in this Pit. Strange Gap below MFcr (240903) in some areas of SZ. possibly from FC that got washed out?

Días previos de calor, el día de hoy muy nublado y frío. Transporte de nieve en alturas por viento fuerte, con ráfagas de viento de hasta 80km/hr. Registros de días previos con avalanchas de nieve húmeda en laderas O y NO

Investigation into Size 2 Skier Accidental On the 26th which failed on old MFcr surface.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Nevada hace 3 días de 13cm de nieve fresca. Alzas de temperatura los recientes dos días y en algunos sectores de exposición O principalmente se aprecian coladas de nieve húmeda.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Skied off the ridge to the sheltered trees to dig a pit.
Predominantly thin and weak pack throughout S1/2 SZ in the HW bowl and the Chutes. S1/2 has no load above this weak pack.
Very thin and weak in BWR 1,2 & 3. Stripped back to rock in the middle of 2. Minimal load in this area

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Extremely weak area as the snowpack continues facet throughout. DH falling out when dug. Crust appear to be breaking down very slowly Perserved SH isolated in the terrain to very sheltered areas.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Eagles Nest - ECTX x2. ECTP31 (Hard hit) @55 on FC below rain crust. Gypsy left - ECTP24 down 60cm on FC below rain crust Lower pack multiple crust and FC layers up to 3.0mm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Lightly trafficked in-bounds slope, experienced previous wind loading from the NW. Wind drifts and stiff surface slabs are connected through start zone of zone 2, isolated drifts in zones 3 and 4.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Mid-Lower pack in this area has remained weak, This pit was dug in a slightly deeper than average location where conditions in the lower pack are slightly improved with higher resistance than areas where HS <100cm. Load creep occurring on the summit

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Upper slab of snowpack is consistent across Zones 1-3 of Pot Belly, 10-25cm in thickness, with similar mid- and low-pack structure found with continuous probing along start zones. Upper slab has consolidated in recent days, producing more reactive test results.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Perfil realizado tras tres días de anticiclón.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug by Grice Adams and Nikki Blair, Upper Hourglass.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug 24 hours after Sa-Sp-Sz2 occurrence on backside of Porters ski boundary, within "Powderbowl". Crown and flanks were observed in detail, with continued touchy results observed directly adjacent to the avalanche.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Profile location dug in ski area, previous tracks before storm unknown.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Collapsing, widespread; Cracking;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Testing reactivity of buried FCsf layer. Used Xe on this slope later in day with cracking and slope collapse, but surprisingly no avalanche. Collapsing and cracking widespread on similar slopes. Slopes needed to lack support to avalanche. Multiple small pockets size 1 Sp on S-SW aspects in the Pinnacles 240809-11.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Collapsing, widespread; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Perfil realizado el día posterior a una tormenta que dejó 42cm a los 3000msnm, y en zonas altas más de 50cms, de nieve muy seca y muy buena calidad. En los controles de avalanchas del día Martes 6 de agosto, una vez finalizada la tormenta y el inicio de un día soleado, se puedo apreciar que muchas coladas de nieve fresca habían ocurrido de forma espontanea, en algunos sectores también aludes de placas friables, por lo que en nuestros controles, tanto con explosivos como con esquíes, cayeron grandes de nieve suelta y en algunos casos de placas friables.

Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank;

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in UB3 "Crown" path. New snow was wind packed and well bonded to the surface below. A large rain crust laminate exists below that was saturated during the last rain event and has not refrozen into a very hard and thick crust. Some faceting is occurring within the laminate but only in very thin, indistinguishable layers. Below this lies basal facets.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snow depth is very variable at the moment 30cm snow depth is the most consistent I found on the SW 1/4. There is a 3-5 cm breakable crust overlying a facet crust sandwich combo No. 9 to ground. This makes for terrible crampon travel.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: ECT tests did not isolate 240601 crust, only representative of stability of upper pack.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Moderate hand shears within the new snow. The new and old snow surface is bonding with CTH23(BRK) down 15 and ECTN down 15 (within the new storm). Grabby snow (knee braking).

Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug well below avalanche start zones, currently no connected slopes in upper SZs in this area. Pit likely held snow from April/May unlike the upper SZs. PST performed for practice, unable to cut through lower crusts. No real slab overlying the tested WL.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: ECT result compromised because cord used for isolating block pulled base of probes into depth hoar. Weather forecast to remain fine with freezing level above 2600m for next 3 days. Consistently warm temperatures likely to be driving a rounding process within the snowpack. Unlikely to see surface hoar production due to very low humidity, but a strong temperature gradient in top 10cm may promote near-surface faceting.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Intention: Observe midpack crust.

Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Período de anticiclón. Debido a las temperaturas y la presencia de vientos, se ha reducido la altura del manto nivoso desde 2,15 a 1,70mts. Se muestra muy estable y las observaciones en terreno también confirman esta percepción.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Isolated areas of wind driven snow in S1/4 SZ, this combined with some settlement of last weeks snow has created a stiffer slab in these SZ. Lower pack has poor structure similar to Summit SZ.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Lower pack appears to be weakening with FC growth observed and crusts breaking down. All tests conducted after cutting crusts.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: SZ has structure on NE facing rib. Does not extend into QH1 Slightly stronger lower pack in this zone compared to other SZ with structure. All Tests preformed cutting all crusts .
Upper IFrc remaining strong and consistent here. Lower IFrc appears to be weakening/decomposing. This structure is consistent with other paths holding snow from May.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug by Che Caballero and Grice Adams of Remarks Patrol

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 20-30 Cm PP/DF past 96 hrs @1900m and above without little wind effect observed, this new addition to the snow pack overlays a relativity poor snow structure (may snow) with multiple Crusts and Fc /DH layers. Currently no avalanche issues has be observed however this could become a problem with >20cm of PPavailable for transport. This layer is to be monitored for change in structure and load

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Representative of E to S start zones above 1800m that held snow late April/May. IFrc (240601) is relatively consistent at 3-5cm across the SZ. There is a third IFrc in the mid pack found with some variability across the terrain. June 1st rain has not soaked this shallow early season pack above 1800m.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
NE through S aspects above 1800m. Upper pack capped by a rime/rain crust dependant on elevation. Well defined faceting regime occurring below this.
Variable conditions at ground with Old snow at ground from late april (250424) and early may (080524) ether preserved as Depth hoar where it was in deeper deposits or a thicker rain crust at ground where it was less thick.
In and out cloud cover with brief but intense green-housing throughout field day.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Större snöfält där det låg jämt med drevsnö, whumf i närheten i 23 graders lutning när jag hoppade av från skotern
Brant västlig snöfält nedanför stenar. borde ha fått en del snö på ostvindar i vinter.
Brant liten sluttning där det låg cirka 40 cm drevsnö. Grävde bara 60 cm, mycket hårt under drevsnön.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 50 cm (20 in) of new snow. Mostly 4F hardness but I could feel various layers with my crystal card. Hard to identify crystals as they would melt quickly on my card in the hot May sunshine. ECTX but stability test results are often unreactive in crowns and flanks. What was most notable is that the old snow underneath was still fairly soft with just a fragle ice crust unlike in many other place where the old snow is hard, icy, and dirty.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Konvex, läformation, testsluttning, HS270+ sonden räckte inte till Testa senaste drevsnön

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug below the deposition area of a fatal avalanche on 5/9/24. 45 cm (18 in) of settled snow from the storm. I could feel various storm layers in the snow but couldn't discern a notable hardness difference. No red flags observed except for the fatal avalanche and one triggered by explosives in the terrain above.
Endast temp. Brant sydvänd snöfält bredvid hängdriva och äldre D2-3 lavin. okänd ålder.

Athugun á áhrifum dægurhitasveiflna á stöðugleikaástand snjóþekjunnar. Athugun á samsetningu og stöðugleika snjóþekjunnar í aðdraganda hlákuveðurs.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit score 8/9. Good strength, good energy, good structure. At this time our primary stability concern will be warming within the new snow producing wet loose avalanches. There was some wind effect and cracking in the new snow but wind slabs should be stubborn and only found in isolated terrain features along ridges. There is still a slight hardness change above the EFC but the snowpack is still a cold winter snowpack. This layer may only become problematic after a long period of warming but even this is unlikely to produce wet slab conditions.
